Michigan Initial Health & Safety Training Module B
Section 1: Administration of Medications

Routes of Administration

To review before the coming exercise, letâ€™s discuss various routes of administration that would be used when giving medications to the children under your care.- Oral, Topical, Inhalants and Automatic Injectables.

Routes Description Examples
Oral Oral medications are taken by mouth, either as pills, tablets, capsules or liquid. They are the most common type. Liquid, Tablets, Capsules, Pills
Topical Topical medications are creams, ointments, and drops such as sunscreen, diaper paste, antibiotic ointment, and eye drops. Creams, Ointments, Drops
Inhalants Inhalants come in the form of nebulizers and sprays. The inhalants you would normally see are for children with asthma and respiratory infections. Nebulizers, Sprays
Automatic Injectable The primary automatic injectables you would administer are Epipen and Twinjet, which are forms of epinephrine used to treat severe allergies that lead to an anaphylactic reaction. EpiPen, Twinject
